entry.title: Differentiating DSA Violations from Common Moderation Issues
entry.content:
Next time you report inappropriate content on SAP Community, you‚Äôll notice that we‚Äôve introduced a new process for identifying why the moderation alert has been raised.

When we updated our moderation methods last year to comply with the Digital Services Act (DSA), we leaned toward a more formal approach for aligning with these new regulations. In doing so, however, we tended to lump all sorts of moderation reports under DSA. As a result, we lost much of the human touch essential to a helpful, cordial moderation program.

To give our moderators more flexibility ‚Äì while ensuring that we continue to adhere to the law for true DSA cases (e.g., content deemed harmful and illegal under these EU rules) ‚Äì we have modified the menus that members use when reporting inappropriate content.

The first step remains the same: You‚Äôll still find the option for reporting inappropriate content from the dropdown menu next to posts, answers, comments, etc., throughout the site. (Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll see when reporting a question, for example.)

Selecting this option will bring you to a series of menus, as well as a text field, allowing you to provide details about why you‚Äôve reported the content ‚Äì while also indicating whether the content actually breaks DSA rules.

In most cases, you‚Äôll simply choose ‚ÄúNon-DSA related alert to moderators‚Äù for the reason ‚Äì as this selection applies to the majority of reports that our moderation team receives (for requests to move content to another area, remove/correct a tag, and so on).

If you pick ‚ÄúNon-DSA related alert to moderators‚Äù as the reason, the ‚ÄúDSA Specification‚Äù menu will remain grayed out. (Since the reason is unrelated to a DSA violation, no additional selection is required.) You‚Äôll still have the option to enter additional information (in the ‚ÄúDetails‚Äù field). For example, you can point out an incorrect tag (and propose a better one) before submitting the report by clicking the ‚ÄúNotify Moderator‚Äù button.

This information helps our moderators understand the nature of the issue and work with members quickly to fix the problem, minus the formality of DSA steps that require stiffly worded messages and legally sounding explanations. In other words, for non-DSA cases, the moderators can work with members in a capacity that doesn‚Äôt feel overly official, rebuilding the trust and connections associated with moderation before we instituted stricter rules under DSA.

In situations where something does violate the DSA, our moderation team will continue to follow DSA procedures. We only ask that you make certain that it‚Äôs a true DSA offense before reporting it as such.

When alerting the moderation team about a DSA violation, you‚Äôll need to select one of the reasons beneath the dashed line (underneath ‚ÄúNon-DSA related alert to moderators‚Äù), such as ‚ÄúIllegal Or Harmful Speech‚Äù and ‚ÄúUnsafe And/Or Illegal Products.‚Äù

This action opens the ‚ÄúDSA Specification‚Äù menu, where you‚Äôll need to select the item related to the reason. There are several to choose.

Since we have mapped these reasons and specifications to DSA systems (which is where we need to upload data about our DSA-related activities), we must make sure that we open and submit every DSA case accurately. You can help by selecting the right reason (distinguishing between non-DSA and DSA alerts) and DSA specification (in the event of actual DSA violations) carefully when reporting content that requires moderation.

Not sure which selection to make? You‚Äôll see some helpful suggestions right next to the menus, providing guidance about what to select and why for common scenarios.

As an example, if you want to report spam, select ‚ÄúViolation of Terms of Use‚Äù for the reason and ‚ÄúOther‚Äù from the ‚ÄúDSA Specification‚Äù menu. (Remember to add some information in the details to help our moderators understand why you‚Äôre reporting the content.)

One last piece of important advice: Negative feedback and curt comments aren‚Äôt against the law, and they don‚Äôt qualify as harassment and hate speech under DSA regulations. To be more specific, as an example, DSA defines hate speech as ‚Äúillegal incitement to violence and hatred based on protected characteristics.‚Äù Therefore, before reporting member comments as misconduct under DSA, consider whether they can be categorized as illegal speech. Per our Basic Etiquette and Tips for Participating in SAP Community guidelines, members should keep discourse civil and try to work out differences, reporting member comments only when they are truly harmful and in violation of DSA regulations. Disagreements and criticism are not grounds for moderator action ‚Äì especially under DSA.

By differentiating non-DSA and DSA reports, we are taking steps to make moderation friendlier ‚Äì freeing it from the rigid steps that we applied when we treated all alerts as DSA cases. At the same time, we‚Äôll continue to ensure that SAP Community complies with DSA, protecting our site and our members from the illegal activities that the regulations cover.

entry.title: SAP Developer News 10th July, 2025
entry.content:
DESCRIPTION

SAP TechEd Community Talk and DemoJam Submissions

  • SAP TechEd Registration https://www.sap.com/events/teched/berlin.html
  • Community Talk Submission blogpost https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-teched-blog-posts/become-part-of-the-sap-teched-family-as-a-community-talk-speaker/ba-p/14103324
  • Community Talk Submission Form https://www.sap.com/events/teched/berlin/flow/sap/te25/cfpct/form/session
  • DemoJam Submission blogpost https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-teched-blog-posts/a-fan-favorite-is-back-in-berlin-demo-jam-sapteched-2025/ba-p/14103360
  • DemoJam Submission Form https://www.sap.com/events/teched/berlin/flow/sap/te25/cfpctdemojam/form/session

SAP Developer License 3.2 CAP

  • CAP License info in Capire https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/resources/cap-license

SAP CodeJam roadshow in Southeast Asia and India

  • SAP CodeJam roadshow in India: https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-codejam-blog-posts/sap-integration-suite-codejam-roadshow-in-india/ba-p/14110730

Transition from SAP Build Work Zone, Standard to SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition

  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/a-comprehensive-guide-to-transition-from-sap-build-work-zone-standard/ba-p/14141857

CAP MCP Plugin

  • Blog Post: https://medium.com/@simonvlaursen/introducing-cap-mcp-transform-your-sap-applications-into-ai-ready-systems-410a01fda5aa
  • GitHub: https://github.com/gavdilabs/cap-mcp-plugin

Code Connect 2025

  • Code Connect Page: https://code-connect.dev/ 

CHAPTER TITLES

0:00 Intro

0:06 Code Connect 2025

3:20 SAP Developer License 3.2 CAP

7:04 SAP TechEd Community Talk and DemoJam Submissions

10:14 CAP MCP Plugin ‚Äì AI with Ease

10:45  Transition from SAP Build Work Zone, Standard to SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition

12:18 SAP CodeJam roadshow in Southeast Asia and India

TRANSCRIPTION :

[Intro] This is the SAP Developer News for July the 10th, 2025.

[DJ, AJAY NICO & VITALI] Hi there, and welcome from St. Leon Rote in Germany, just down the road from the mothership in Waldorf. We're here at Code Connect 2025. It's Wednesday. It's been an amazing week so far, starting with, on Monday, what, Ajay? hello, everyone. Welcome. And on Monday, we had two Code Jams running in parallel, one for cap and one for ui5 and we had jam-packed rooms and it was really exciting so to see all of you there and it was a very good weather as well over over to you nico thanks yeah so the day after on tuesday we had ui5 con and my personal highlight was meeting many of you the developers and talk tech and also my to-do list of things i want to try out is getting longer and longer the longer of the week gets there's just so much inspiration out here so that was very cool and what happened today dj what happened today that's wednesday was recap recap 2025 um i love this event i love code connect generally but specifically recap again just like nico meeting you folks but learning from you folks learning from everybody everybody from the sessions from the corridor conversations it's just humbling to see so many big brains and so many humble people so many modest people here at the event and we've got something special tomorrow as well as part of the code connect event what is it vitaly so for the very first time code connect family is getting a new child which is HANA techcon and we are really looking for that because the idea came to us last year during the code connect and we really wanted to get hana into the family of all the other technologies at sap so probably you're looking this on friday and we are recording this on wednesday and the event is happening for hana tech con tomorrow so i don't know what would be the proper english phrase to welcome all of those who are looking on friday sorry watching on friday for the event that is going to happen tomorrow while we are recording on wednesday had it have ever happened have it happened yet a universal welcome how about that a universal wealth a universal welcome okay so that's us wrapping it up it's now time for the post recap celebrations downstairs so we're off now have a great evening great morning great afternoon bye for now cheers cheers bye fast forward to thursday and here i am at hana techcon. As we mentioned, it is the very first time we have it. I'm really glad there are many participants joining. There are many people watching this live. And as well, rest assured that we will provide recordings available for you as well. I would like to welcome as well our SAP community team here. If you didn't get a chance or if you haven't had a chance to visit that table here today and to collect all these beautiful stickers, make sure that you stop by one of our SAP CodeJam this year and you get them as well.

[DJ & Oler] Hi there, folks. So we're at Recap 2025, part of Code Connects, this week here in Saliar Road. And I'm very happy to have grabbed Ola for a short time. Ola Lilienthal, head of the CAP organization. And I'm going to ask Ola to talk to us a little bit about one of the topics in his opening taught this morning.welcome, first of all. Thank you so much, DJ, for having me. Well, thanks for being here. So, one of the topics which came hand-in-hand with the annual major release of Cap, which is Cap 9, Node.js 9, which was out in May this year, right, Reg? Also, at the same time, there's a new developer license, developer license 3.2 Cap, is that right? That's great. Can you tell us a little bit about that? Of course. Thanks for giving me the opportunity. Look, there have been a lot of customers and partners approaching us in the past and asking us specific questions about how they can use CAP and in which scenario. And actually, there was some ambiguity in that license and the old license and the developer license. And so we had two ways of handling it. one was we always get into discussions with legal to get explanations of how to interpret that license yes yeah and to then give answers to customers but you don't really want to be in that situation to interpret legal tech it doesn't help you to give your customers answers right so the second approach was let's get those ambiguities fixed let's work on that license so we got together was legal and we formulated some things differently in yet cup specific available license and the gist of it is basically that if you're using CAP as a developer for testing purposes for developing purposes for educational purposes research anything anything you can do that we are happy to for you to use CAP and try it out if you're making money with it if you're using it in a productive scenario we want you to do that or let the productive application run on an sap license but right yeah so today this is either sap BTP or also XSA and that's what we ask you. And in return, we make it really clear that if you do so, you get full support for that CAP application on that platform from us, as I say. That's great. I mean, that's a nice, clear direction. The door's not completely closed yet, right? So it's a journey. Yes. So we are still discussing about the process of open sourcing CAP further. As you all might know, we had a lot of CAP components which we open sourced in the past. over the last years and so that journey is still kind of ongoing um but there are a lot of discussions um in how how far we go here if we also open source the core of cup um and that's still kind of an an open journey i would say yeah and you still continue on that journey um but it's not really decided exactly and in the meantime we have the capjs.org on github and that's you know the you know the nearest part of the journey okay well you heard it here first first folks so oler thanks very much for joining us thanks so much i think it's now time for a uh maybe a small beer maybe a small or beverage we're told beverage yes beverage of choice okay thanks oler thanks so much great

[Bentley & Anne] hey everybody it's Josh bentley i'm a community advocate and i'm with Anne who is also a community advocate and we're so happy to be reporting live from the beautiful SAP campus here in Waldorf, Germany. We're prepping for one of our favorite events, which is SAP TechEd. It's going to be on site in Berlin, November 4th through 6th. And we've got a couple of great things that are being promoted by our colleague, Cecilia Wergo, with some blog posts. Lots of information to talk about. And I'm going to let Anne tell you about one of the great things you can submit right now. What is it? We're bringing back the SAP Community Talks. Do you want to share or talk about anything you learned experiences cool demos you built technology you worked with this is your opportunity to submit a talk the submission date is july 14th it's coming up shortly so think fast it's a monday you have all weekend all weekend to work on your submission. Then on July 22nd, we will let everyone know the submission status, if it was accepted or declined. As part of the process, you'll be assigned a developer advocate who will help you through the process. Kind of like a buddy, just to help you get set up in the community theater, which will be on-site in our community clubhouse. Yes. And the developer advocate will reach out to you at the end of July. So we're going to have 20 of these available. These are talks of 20 minutes and what's really cool is you get what's called a lecture pass. So it's a free ticket to be on-site in Berlin. We do not cover travel and expense but you will be able to go onto the show floor as a speaker and attend everything happening at TechEd. The lecture pass does not entitle you to the hands-on workshops. Those you can actually increase your access by paying the difference in price between the free ticket and a full price pass. The other thing we have is another huge community favorite coming back on stage demo jam so lots of people are going to want to be on stage in demo jam showcasing all the great things they build with btp all the great code that they know about and that they can do things with btp the trick is you need to actually get a lot of team members together and submit a proposal that we can look at and see if it's going to be one of the ones we select and this process is happening now through the end of july july. once that's done we're going to go into a selection committee and then do some interviews and select different teams that we will then invite to be on stage the top six yes six will be on stage and you'll have six minutes and you will not be allowed to go over and we'll buzz you off stage and then after that we'll have our plaza meter and it will judge who the best one was and the winner of demo jam and you'll get the trophy if we can find it if we can find it yes exactly it's somewhere around here so that's it we've got demo jam tickets as well so the top teams that are selected those six teams will get to have two people on stage with the same lecture passes and remember no slides exactly no slides no ai generated content yes real thing real thing little people real community connecting yeah all right we will see you in Berlin. Bye. Bye.

 

[NICO & SIMON] Hi, everyone, and welcome to the SAP Devolver News. We're here at CodeConnect, and I happen to bump into Simon, who just last week published the CDS MCP plugin. So who's better to introduce it than Simon himself? Yeah, thank you. The CAP MCP plugin is basically a plugin that allows you to handle model context protocols for your OData service directly in CAP. It's PluginPlay. And yeah, check out the link and description. All right. Hope to talk to you soon. Bye.

[Rekha] Hello, everybody. Are you looking to step up your central point of entry user experience from SAP Build Work Zone Standard Edition, which was previously called SAP Fury Launchpad to SAP Build Work Zone Advanced Edition on SAP BTP? Then here is an in-depth structured guidance to achieve the same. In this blog post written by our SAP Build Works on Product Manager Yumna Abbasi, you could understand the overview of SAP Build Works on Standard Edition and SAP Build Works on Advanced Edition. The key differences between these two offerings, information regarding the subscription and service plans, end-to-end transition path. Under transition, crucial steps like accessing the current implementation, planning the migration, exporting the content, setting up SAP billboards on advanced edition, content migration, how to use the existing configurations, best practices to follow during implementation, testing, validation, change management, and go live are well documented. Get ready to provide your business users a multimedia rich user experience with SAP Build WorkZone Advanced Edition. For more details, refer to the blog post. Link is provided in the description box. Thank you.

[Shila,Sheena & Shrini] It was a good mix of SAP customers and partners, making it a true community event. How was your experience, Sheena? It was great, Shilpa. And what I loved the most is that they follow our SAP developers YouTube channel and they like our content. That's so cool, right? And where are you heading next? So I'm heading to Kuala Lumpur first, where Shini will join me. And then we'll both fly together to Bangkok for the next set of code jams. Good luck. Thank you. We are in the SAP Thailand office in Bangkok, where we just finished SAP Gen AI Code Jam. Before coming here, we were in Kuala Lumpur, where we conducted the SAP Build Code Jam. So, Shirni, how did you feel about the SAP Code Jam Roadshow across Southeast Asia? This is the first time we are doing a Code Jam in this region. We've had many of our SAP developers from our customers and partners attend these events. It was exciting to hear their feedback and discuss the latest innovations happening in the BTP space, especially on SAP Gen AI topics. So, yeah, it was interesting, Code Jam. So, Sheena, what is happening next week? Yeah, the team is having a jam-packed schedule with Antonio traveling to India to join Ajay for the next set of integration suite Code Jam Roadshow across various locations in India. So, stay tuned for further updates.

entry.title: Blog It Forward Roberta Fernandes
entry.content:
London, UK

I think one of my greatest passions is the city of London.
The first time I saw Parliament was in my 5th-grade English textbook, and it changed my mindset and my desires. My focus was always on seeing London. I've been to the Queen's Land four times and always want to go back. I did an english  exchange program, and I honestly get excited just looking at photos of London.

 

First time 1.998Hyde Park, 200220162023

 

 

 

 

 

 

My mom Cleonice and Marcos Paulo
My mother is only 16 years older than me, and we have a very good relationship. I always take her out and enjoy the good times we have together. After all, I have seven other siblings, and we can't always be out and about. 

 

At home

 

 Marcos Paulo¬¥s my boyfriend!!

My relationship with Marcos has 4 years and he have good moments together and  is good to  have his support

. 

SAP Community

Being part of the SAP community is great fun. When I met Marssel in person in 2017 in Bras√≠lia, that was the beginning of this new time. Soon, we talked about hosting SAP events, and we've never stopped. It's wonderful to be with the community and see the difference we can make in the lives of each participant.

 

About my activity in SAP world, I recently shared my story in th SAP Community Member Spotlight. My social media are  Linkedin and Instagram), while I am working on SAP projects and actively driving events and supporting SAP Community events. To be a part of SAP Community is a chance to be a part of a major proposal in this life because all our actions impact many people's lives. 

Many thanks folk for all supporting and special thanks to  @Marssel700 .

Now focus in Marssel¬¥s question:

With S/4HANA, RISE with SAP, and BTP evolving rapidly, what do you think is essential for SAP clients to stay ahead in technology and digital transformation in the coming years?

For SAP customers to stay ahead in digital transformation, continuous evolution withSAP S/4HANA, RISE with SAP e SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) is crucial. This is no longer an option, but a necessity.

Keep Clean Core : Minimize customizations and use standard S/4HANA functionality to facilitate upgrades and innovations and Adopt industry best practices. Using Rise with full  package ( Signavio, BTP, HANA Cloud and business process) 

Invest in training and have a huge governance. Invest in IA to help the Company transformation .

I would like to Blog it forward to  @Jonys_Arcanjo , He is new SAP Champion as me. And my question is what¬¥s is next step as SAP Champion, how this position impact your life?

entry.title: SAP Community Team Spotlight: Laura Schmitz - July 2025 Edition
entry.content:
You might have seen our iterations of recognizing active authors (one / two / three / four / five / six)  in SAP Community. We also want to introduce the team behind the SAP Community platform. This month we want to introduce @lauraschmitz  to you which I interviewed recently. Read more about how she got started and what her day to day looks like behind the scenes of the SAP Community.


Marco Santos (MS): I'm super happy that you've decided to join us today. Laura, thank you so much for being here. It's a great pleasure to feature you as our next Community Team Member Spotlight on SAP Community.

Laura Schmitz: Thank you, Marco! I'm also very delighted to be part of this interview. I really appreciate the opportunity.

MS: Awesome. All right, let‚Äôs start with an easy one. How did you originally get involved with the SAP Community?

Laura Schmitz: I got involved with the SAP Community through my second role at SAP. I originally joined the company as a working student in 2018, supporting the learning organization. After finishing my studies in 2020, I applied internally for a Community Advocate role and that‚Äôs when I really started getting to know the SAP Community. I‚Äôd heard about it now and then in my first role, but I hadn‚Äôt really interacted with it until I joined the team.

MS: That‚Äôs great to hear! So, you've been on the team for a few years now, but could you tell us a bit more about your current role on the community team and what your day-to-day typically looks like?

Laura Schmitz: Sure! My current role is Community Event Lead, which means I focus on the strategy and overall concept of community events globally. A big part of my job is helping event organizers by supporting them with everything they need to run successful events for their local communities. I also make sure that these efforts are aligned with our broader SAP Community strategy.

MS: Sounds like a big responsibility!

Laura Schmitz: It definitely keeps things exciting! There‚Äôs no such thing as a completely typical day, but a common task is reviewing applications from people who are interested in becoming event organizers. I run interviews with them, guide them through onboarding, and ensure any new locations they represent are properly added to our platform.

MS: So you‚Äôre kind of a matchmaker for new communities?

Laura: That‚Äôs a good way to put it! I also proactively look into regions we haven‚Äôt reached yet and try to find engaged community members who might want to help build something there. Beyond that, I stay in regular contact with existing organizers by discussing their upcoming events, helping them with financial or promotional support, and looking for opportunities for our community team to be present at those events as well.

MS: That already sounds like a very full day! All right, let‚Äôs move on to the next question. Can you share a particularly memorable moment from your time working with the community?

Laura Schmitz: That would definitely be attending my very first SAP Inside Track. It was in ‚Äòs-Hertogenbosch, in the Netherlands, back in 2022.

It was really special for me because I had joined the community team during COVID. Everyone kept telling me how amazing these events were, and I saw pictures and posts, but I never truly understood what made them so great until I experienced one myself.

The vibe was just incredible! So casual and fun, but also filled with value and genuine knowledge-sharing. And what stood out the most was how welcoming everyone was. People were just happy to connect, learn, and share with each other. I‚Äôll never forget that experience of finally understanding what community is about.

MS: Yeah, I definitely agree. Meeting people in person: nothing beats that for really understanding what a community is all about.

Now, moving on to the next question: You're in contact with many event organizers and community members. How do you stay in touch with community needs and feedback?

Laura Schmitz: Since my focus is mainly on community events, most of the feedback I receive comes directly from the event organizers. They know they can always reach out, often via email, but we also have a dedicated private group on the SAP Community platform. It‚Äôs our main space for communication, resource sharing, and best practice exchange. And it also acts as a feedback channel.

In addition to that, we meet on a quarterly basis with all organizers globally. During those sessions, we share updates, but more importantly, we listen to their needs and concerns. We try our best to address their feedback, even if we can‚Äôt act on every single request. For me, having that close, open, and transparent relationship with the organizers is really essential.

Marco Santos: That‚Äôs great to hear. Sounds like a very organic and ongoing way to stay in touch with what‚Äôs happening on the ground. All right, next up: what do you enjoy most about working on the SAP Community?

Laura Schmitz: It‚Äôs definitely the people! Connecting with people. Of course, I spend a lot of time being online, behind the scenes and working on the platform, but what really brings me joy is the one-on-one interaction. Whether it's working with a group of organizers in a specific city or hearing about someone‚Äôs journey, those connections are what make this role so meaningful.

Every local community is different. Every organizer team has their own way of doing things. That diversity, that authenticity, is what I find so special about this work.

MS: That‚Äôs great to hear and a lovely answer! We‚Äôve talked a lot about the past and how you got involved in the community. Now, let‚Äôs talk about the future: What‚Äôs one thing you‚Äôd love to see more of in the SAP Community going forward?

Laura Schmitz: More in-person connections among community members, and continuous relationship building between our team and community members. That‚Äôs definitely something I‚Äôd love to see continuing and growing. And also adding new locations to the map, we still have some regions that aren‚Äôt yet represented in our community. A great example is the Middle East, which has recently started getting involved with their very first SAP CodeJam in Dubai. Now, the organizer wants to establish more community events in the region and connect people on a regular basis. I‚Äôd love to see that trend continue. The more local communities we can support, the better.

MS: Sounds like a solid plan. More events, more locations leads to more connection! Okay, and now to wrap things up: Is there anything else you‚Äôd like to share with the audience? Anything we didn‚Äôt cover that you‚Äôd like to add?

Laura Schmitz: I‚Äôd like to encourage community members to get active and to engage in their local community - by joining a community event near you or organize your own. There‚Äôs a common misconception that you need to be a professional organizer, an expert, or someone with years of experience to lead something meaningful in your community. But the truth is - anyone can start. Real impact often begins with simple actions: a shared interest and a handful of people who just want to connect. And if this this resonates with you and you feel inspired to take that first step, we‚Äôd love to hear from you, so reach out and let‚Äôs explore what we can build together.

MS: That‚Äôs a perfect way to close it out. Thank you so much, Laura, for joining me today: sharing your journey, your day-to-day, and your vision for the future of the SAP Community. It was great having you here.

Laura Schmitz: Thanks again, Marco. It‚Äôs been a pleasure!

entry.title: Raja Gupta
entry.content:
More about Raja Gupta in SAP Community


First Name, Last Name: Raja Gupta
Location (City, Country): Bangalore, India
Occupation: Solution Architect, SAP

 


Raja, tell us about yourself.
Who are you, what do you like to do, what is important to you?

I'm Raja Gupta, a solution architect with over 17 years of experience in SAP. Throughout my career, I‚Äôve led multiple implementation projects and currently work with SAP Partners to co-innovate and build solutions using BTP and AI.

I'm also the author of several SAP-focused books, a regular speaker at global SAP events, and an active contributor to the SAP community through mentoring, blogging, and training. You can find the list of all my books on SAP-Press site  and read of my blogs on SAP Community.

What truly drives me is the joy of sharing knowledge - whether it‚Äôs through writing, speaking, or engaging with my 43K+ LinkedIn followers on topics around SAP and AI.

I‚Äôm based out of Bangalore. When I‚Äôm not working, I‚Äôm usually spending time with my kids and family, reading, or planning our next family trip.


What is your area of expertise?
What does a usual day at work look like for you?

I specialize in SAP BTP, SAP Business AI, Joule, Generative AI, and related technologies.

I work closely with SAP Partners to onboard them to SAP Business AI and Joule, guiding them in building real-world solutions. I deliver technical workshops and enablement sessions across various SAP Business AI and BTP topics, often customized for partner-specific needs.

My day typically involves hands-on collaboration with partners, activating SAP Business AI, addressing technical challenges, and enabling partners to adopt SAP‚Äôs latest innovations effectively.

Outside of that, I regularly write, train, and mentor within the SAP ecosystem, sharing insights through blogs and community platforms.


What inspired you to become an SAP Champion in SAP Community?

I started engaging with the SAP Community in 2016, when I published my first blog post. What began as a simple attempt to share a few thoughts quickly turned into something much more meaningful ‚Äî I found a space where people supported each other and where learning didn‚Äôt feel one-sided.

Over time, I‚Äôve learned a lot from this community, and that naturally created a sense of responsibility to contribute in return. Whether it‚Äôs writing blog posts, speaking at events, or simply answering a question, I‚Äôve seen the real impact of open knowledge-sharing.

As someone who spends a lot of time delivering trainings, and enablement sessions, the SAP Champion role felt like a natural extension of what I already do. It allows me to stay connected with the community, support peer learning, and continue contributing in a more focused and visible way.


How do you learn in SAP Community?
What is your daily/weekly routine in SAP Community?

Each morning, I spend the first 30 minutes of my workday either reading something new or drafting content to share with the community. This small but consistent routine keeps me in sync with what‚Äôs happening, and also pushes me to contribute back regularly.

I‚Äôve made the SAP Community a regular part of my learning routine. I follow a set of topics closely and make it a habit to visit their pages frequently to stay updated. I‚Äôve also subscribed to SAP newsletters and topic-specific notifications. These notifications helps me to check in and explore new posts, questions, and discussions.


What is your suggestion to get the most out of SAP Community?

Here are three things that have worked well for me and might help others get more value from the SAP Community:

Follow topics that genuinely interest you.
Don‚Äôt try to keep up with everything. Pick a few areas you're working on or curious about and make it a habit to check their pages regularly. The focused approach helps you stay updated without getting overwhelmed.

Build a simple weekly rhythm.
You don‚Äôt need hours. Even spending 15‚Äì30 minutes a day reading a blog post, answering a question, or sharing a quick thought can keep you connected and sharp. I personally begin my day with this and it keeps me in sync with what's moving in the ecosystem.

Look beyond the screen.
There‚Äôs real value in attending SAP Community events for example SAP Inside Track, CodeJam etc. These are great places to meet others working on similar things, ask questions you wouldn‚Äôt post online, and build lasting connections.

Raja's question to you:
If you could give one piece of advice to someone new to the SAP Community, what would it be ‚Äî and why?

entry.title: Antonio de Ancos
entry.content:
More about Antonio de Ancos in SAP Community


First Name, Last Name: Antonio de Ancos
Location (City, Country): Madrid, Spain
Occupation: Consultant and Instructor

 

 


Antonio, tell us about yourself.
Who are you, what do you like to do, what is important to you?

I am a lifelong learner and an ‚Äúoccasional‚Äù teacher. I believe we live in an age where all kinds of knowledge are at our fingertips, which can sometimes be overwhelming; that‚Äôs why my main work is helping others learn faster and more easily. I enjoy sharing good meals with friends, playing sports, and diving into a great book.


What is your area of expertise?
What does a usual day at work look like for you?

I started in 1997 programming ABAP, specifically in the HR module. From there I explored the entire functional side without ever leaving the technical world behind, which led me to wrestling with SAP BTP since its early days (HCP, SCP‚Ä¶). I‚Äôve been an official SAP instructor for over 20 years in both HCM and Technology areas.


What inspired you to become an SAP Champion in SAP Community?


I didn‚Äôt do anything special to become an SAP Champion; someone nominated me, and here I am üòâ. I suppose it has something to do with the content I‚Äôve been creating in Spanish over the years‚Äîthrough my blog (www.aancos.com), social media, and a couple of podcasts where I share my professional journey (www.memoriasdeunconsultor.com) and chat with ecosystem experts (www.hablamosdesap.com), including several SAP Champions.


How do you learn in SAP Community?
What is your daily/weekly routine in SAP Community?

In SAP Community I learn from others, since there are people with deep expertise in many of the areas I‚Äôm interested in. I find it always easier to learn when someone guides you, although I don‚Äôt follow a strict routine.


What is your suggestion to get the most out of SAP Community?

I think it‚Äôs important to clearly identify a few key thought leaders and accept that you can‚Äôt keep up with everything‚Äîyou risk getting lost in the vast ocean of knowledge. Often, less is more; knowing where to focus is essential.

Antonio's question to you:
Here‚Äôs my thought-provoking question: English is undoubtedly the universal language in the technical world, and in SAP in particular (with all due respect to German), so why not create more content for the Spanish-speaking community in their own language?

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite CodeJam roadshow in India - recap
entry.content:
What an eventful week it was! (No pun intended)..... Together with @ajay_soreng, we did one SAP CodeJam per day - 3 different cities (Mumbai, Hyderabad, and Bengaluru), 5 different locations, 3 different topics (SAP Integration Suite, SAP Build Process Automation, and SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh).

Everything was planned to perfection but I had a mental misstep. I mistakenly thought that there was a visa on arrival when traveling to India when in reality it requires applying for an e-visa. Unfortunately, I only found this when I was doing my check-in - Saturday, exactly 12 hours before my flight, a bit late right? I immediately applied for an e-visa but given that it was a Saturday I had to wait till Monday for a resolution. Don't get me wrong, the e-visa process is really good and fast but you can't expect much when you end up applying for it too late.

The adventure only starts here...I joined the first event remotely, from Madrid. Once I receive the e-visa approval, I had 4.5 hours to catch the next plane leaving Madrid heading to India. The second event, I also joined it remotely, but this time from Abu Dhabi. The plane touched ground at 06:35, after going through security, I immediate started searching for a quiet place to join the 2nd CodeJam of the week. Fortunately, I found one :-). Straight after the event, I boarded a plane to Hyderabad - not kidding, I was walking to the gate as we were wrapping up the event. I closed my laptop a minute before boarding. Finally, I made it to Hyderabad Tuesday night and I was able to join the last three events in-person. I sincerely want to apologise to the attendees of the first two events as I wasn't able to be there in-person but it was great meeting you virtually; also, doing the event remotely would have not been possible if it wasn't for the great help and support from @ajay_soreng and @Shilpa_Shankar - Thanks to you both!

Apart from the physical badges (stickers) that many of the attendees got. All attendees of the different SAP CodeJams will get a special SAP Community badge for attending the events ü™™.

 

 

Mumbai

In Mumbai we did the Connecting systems and services using SAP Integration Suite CodeJam at Colgate office. Thanks Colgate for hosting!

We recently introduced a new exercise where we interact with Slack and send notifications from Cloud Integration to Slack. It was exciting to see many attendees posting their notifications even after the event finished.

Hyderabad

In Hyderabad it was all about SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh. We ran the Event-driven integrations CodeJam at two different locations. Thanks Mindset and Infosys for hosting the events. I joined the first one remotely from Abu Dhabi and finally in-person for the second event. 

Bengaluru

Last city part of the SAP Integration Suite CodeJam roadshow. At Bengaluru, we ran the new SAP Build: Event-based processes and also the Connecting systems and services with SAP Integration Suite CodeJams at SAP Labs Bengaluru and Mindset Consulting, thanks for hosting. We were fortunate enough to be joined by the entire SAP Developer Advocates team based in India ( @sheenamk, @eshrinivasan, @Rekha_DR, @Shilpa_Shankar), as well as by @acharyaw - PM for SAP Build Process Automation.

 

Food

Last but certainly not least... all the lovely food that we enjoyed as part of the roadshow. Thanks to all the hosts.... the food was amazing everywhere haha.

Lots of lessons learned from the mental misstep and there might be cool things and opportunities coming up thanks to it. Also, this wouldn't have been possible without @ajay_soreng's help organising the events and supporting me while I was remotely - Thanks!

entry.title: Welcome Message ‚Äì SAP Community Joinville, Brazil
entry.content:
Hello everyone, and welcome to the SAP Community Group in Joinville, Brazil!

Joinville is a city located in the south of Brazil, in the state of Santa Catarina. It has a rich historical background, originally founded in 1851 as part of a land grant from the French royal family to Prince Fran√ßois Ferdinand of Orl√©ans. Soon after, Joinville became home to a large wave of German, Swiss, and Norwegian immigrants, which shaped its culture, architecture, and traditions that remain vibrant to this day.

Often called the ‚ÄúCity of Flowers‚Äù and ‚ÄúCity of Princes,‚Äù Joinville is also famous for hosting the Joinville Dance Festival, one of the largest dance festivals in the world. Its combination of European heritage and Brazilian warmth creates a unique cultural atmosphere.

Today, Joinville is recognized as one of Brazil‚Äôs most important industrial and technological hubs, leading innovation in sectors such as software development, automotive, and manufacturing. This thriving economy has helped position the city as a strategic center for digital transformation and SAP-related opportunities.

This group is created to connect SAP professionals, students, and enthusiasts in the region, fostering collaboration, networking, and continuous learning. We invite you to share insights, ask questions, and contribute to building a strong and dynamic SAP community here in Joinville.

Welcome aboard ‚Äì let‚Äôs grow together!

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Munich 2025 | Call for Speakers üì¢ #sitMUC25
entry.content:
The SAP Inside Track Munich (#sitMUC) is back ...

Dear SAP Community,

On October 11th, the SAP community will gather once again in Garching for a day full of learning, sharing, and connecting .. and we want you to be part of it.

Whether you're deep into ABAP, building apps on SAP BTP, working with Fiori, S/4HANA, or Analytics, exploring DevOps in SAP, or shaping business processes, driving change in projects, or navigating transformation from a consulting perspective, your insights matter. Our audience comes from all corners of the SAP universe: developers, consultants, architects, product experts, and curious newcomers. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre looking for diverse session ideas: technical deep dives, lessons learned from projects, open-source initiatives, or even side projects that others can learn from. It doesn‚Äôt have to be perfect or polished. If it‚Äôs real and relevant to the community, it belongs on stage.

Important dates and submission process:

  • Call opens: July 24st
  • Submission deadline: August 30th
  • Speaker selection: by September 5th
  • Please submit your proposal using our online form:
    sitmuc.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com

There are various session types for your submissions:

  • Short Presentation (20 min)
  • Presentation (40 min)
    you will present a topic to the audience demos, theory, live coding, or anything else that suits your expertise
  • Marketplace
    you will share your topic in a ‚Äúmarketplace‚Äù breakout session where everyone is welcome to walk around, visit the various stands, and interact

What we‚Äôre looking for:

  • On-site only we‚Äôll be together in person!
  • No marketing pitches ‚Äì just genuine value for the community

We‚Äôd love to hear your ideas whether you‚Äôre a seasoned speaker or presenting for the very first time. Let‚Äôs make #sitMUC25 another unforgettable community event.

If you're unsure about your topic, format, or how to present it no worries! Just drop us an email at sitmuc.orga@gmail.com, we're happy to help. Or better yet: join our next Stammtisch meetup (14.08.), and let‚Äôs chat about your session idea in person.

Let‚Äôs build this day together. Bring your voice, your story, your topic. We can‚Äôt wait to hear it!

Best regards,
sitMUC Orga team

entry.title: A Look Back At CodeConnect 2025
entry.content:
A Look Back At CodeConnect 2025

It's been almost 2 weeks now since I participated in the 2025 CodeConnect event, which was actually my first in-person CodeConnect ever.
I would've participated in person sooner, but getting tickets is akin to trying to get the most popular item on Black Friday, it requires speed, precision and luck!

But enough rambling about the tickets! Let's take a look back at my journey to CodeConnect 2025.

UI5Con 2025

I'm going to skip the very first day of CodeConnect, mainly due to it being spent in a car for 16 hours, as me and my colleagues made the journey from the northern part of Jutland to St. Leon Rot.
So for us, the conference didn't start until day 2 with UI5Con, and that was some start.

Upon arrival at the building, it was straight into networking and trying to decide what sessions were most interesting to participate in.
We ended up doing a divide and conquer strategy in our group to get the most out of the day, with of course a focus on getting to the hands-on sessions.

My day quickly became side-tracked as I caught up with both old and new faces in my effort to connect with all the other developers present at the event.
Which, to be honest, for a mostly backend/cloud guy like me wasn't all bad. While I do enjoy a tango with the frontend from time to time, my heart belongs to what goes on behind the scenes.

But I did catch a lot of good talks still; so here are my take-aways from the first real day at CodeConnect:

  • Ownership of styling is slowly being handed back to the developer, meaning we can now make proper custom components for UI5 that style correctly with the themes such as Horizon.
  • Still no clear release date for UI5 v2, but we do have a legacy free 1.136 out there now that we can utilize and prepare with
  • Promise for UI5 developers that keep in line with the UI5 Linter, that their code will be lift and shift (i.e. go use the linter asap!)
  • The UI5 repository has completed its moving phase and is now living in its own repository
  • Accessibility, much like everywhere else in the developer space at the moment, is the talk of the town, and SAP is doing a lot of improvements on this front
  • 2 test runners were presented as the replacements for the deprecated Karma runner. I know that I am leaning the most towards the WDI5 route due to it working as a more complete suite.
  • Webcomponents are the main focus going forward, and even though there is no timestamp on it, it seems like it will replace many of our current components going forward

That was pretty much my experience and take-aways for the first day there, and with it we wrapped up the UI5Con with some great food before heading back to the hotel.
The next for me, I knew would be something special.

reCAP 2025

Second day for me at CodeConnect started out with a great opening key note by Daniel Hutzel. Although he ran out of time by the end, I wish we could've listened to him for just a little while longer.

The key take-away of this keynote however, was extremely clear. Over the last year, the focus by the CAP team has really been on minimizing the footprint of the CAP/CDS install while optimizing and improving the feature set of the framework.
And from what we were presented, that definitely looked like it came out as a success. As a developer that uses CAP on a daily basis, both for plugin development and end-user projects, I can definitely say that I have enjoyed the improvements so far.

So a kudos to the CAP team is definitely in order on this! (Now we just need it to be open source!)

Unfortunately, I did not have as much time to participate in the many sessions of this day, as much like the day before, the event became more of a networking experience.
The sessions I did catch however, were absolutely great and definitely something that you should catch up on if you have the chance;

  • Both sessions by Mike Zaschka (just always a good listen and everybody loves open source!)
  • CAP Tools session by Christian Georgi (because you cannot be a good developer without knowing your tools)
  • Server-side Pre-rendering by Volker Buzek and Wouter Lemaire (a great session with insights into another great open source initiative)
  • CAP Best vs Bad Practices by Daniel Hutzel
  • Gain a superpower by learning how to harness the CDS REPL by DJ Adams (seriously, learn REPL)

While these were the only sessions I managed to catch, I did however experience something extremely important during the reCAP event, and that was the community.

I got to connect with so many great people and talk about the passion of this side of the industry, and the love we all share for opens source technologies.

I even got the chance to appear on the SAP Developer News to share my own open source contribution (MCP Plugin for CAP).

And that is something I wouldn't trade for anything.

You Should Attend

I hope it is clear from my post here that going to CodeConnect is an experience, no matter how you plan it. It is an event filled with great people and some great discussions around the subjects we all work with on a daily basis.

Never in a million years would I have imagined that going to CodeConnect would have resulted in me getting to participate in the SAP Developer News, nor that I would get to have great open discussions with other open source contributors.
It is definitely worth it, so if you get the chance I highly recommend that you participate!

Hopefully I will get the chance to contribute to the speakers list next year!

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Hyderabad 2nd Edition: Join Us on 23 August 2025
entry.content:
We are pleased to announce the return of SAP Inside Track Hyderabad  2025  2nd Edition on 23 August 2025 . This  event promises to be an enhanced experience, bringing together SAP enthusiasts, experts, and professionals for a day dedicated to insightful sessions, networking opportunities, and discussions on innovation.

Registration is now open, and we encourage you to secure your participation for this highly anticipated event.

What is SAP Inside Track?‚ÄØ  
SAP Inside Track is a community-driven event where SAP professionals, developers, consultants, architects, and leaders come together to share their knowledge and insights on various SAP-related topics. This grassroots initiative, organized by members of the SAP Community, provides a platform for fostering connections, staying updated on the latest SAP technologies, and gaining recognition for your technical expertise. 
Know more about SAP Inside Track Here!

 

Event Highlights

  1. Expert-Led Sessions
    • Keynote Speeches
    • Technical Deep Dives
    • Hands-On Workshops
  2. Networking Opportunities
    • Meet the Experts
    • Community Building

Why Attend?

  • Expand Your Knowledge: Gain insights into the latest SAP technologies and trends.
  • Enhance Your Skills: Participate in hands-on workshops and technical sessions.
  • Grow Your Network: Connect with like-minded professionals and industry experts.
  • Get Inspired: Discover new ideas and innovative solutions that can transform your business.

Event Details

  • Date: Aug 23, 2025
  • Time: 9:00 AM - 4:00 PM
  • Venue: CMRTC Group of Instituions, Hyderabad

We look forward to seeing you at SAP Inside Track Hyderabad 2025 2nd Edition! 

 

Navigate Your SAP Career Path being a Student

Are you looking to build a career in SAP? This is your opportunity to gain a clear understanding of what it takes.

You'll get insights into:

  • How to start career in SAP.

  • The essential SAP skilling roadmap to guide your learning journey.

  • The specific skills and competencies required to secure an SAP job.

Don't miss out on understanding the critical steps to accelerate your professional growth in the SAP ecosystem.

A Dedicated SAP Awarness Track for Institional Students

entry.title: The Return of SAP Community Voice!
entry.content:
Last seen in October of last year, SAP Community Voice was our online newsletter, replacing the email version that had gone out to subscribers for many years. Now after a long hiatus, we‚Äôre bringing the online edition back!

SAP Community Voice highlights popular posts, important community news, upcoming events, and more. If you‚Äôre interested in hot SAP Community content and announcements, look no further. You‚Äôll find it all summarized here.

This edition covers items from the last four weeks or so, and future editions will aim to deliver even more timely information on a regular basis. Make sure to subscribe to the SAP Community Voice label so you don‚Äôt miss any issues of our online newsletter!

 

Featured Content

 

Heartiest Congratulations to Our Newest SAP Champions!

SAP Champions include some of the best and brightest SAP Community members, and this month, my colleague @KatherineKenneally welcomes eight new people to the program. To learn more about them (and about the program), check out her post and find out how you can connect with SAP Champions in your region!

Read the blog post

 

The Complete Guide to Calling Actions in UI5 with Custom Code

Prolific SAP Community contributor @Marian_Zeis has published a blog post that will help you trigger OData actions and functions from UI5 like a pro -- no matter whether you‚Äôre using SAP Fiori elements or going purely freestyle (v2 or v4). This guide walks through every official API, shows exactly when to pick each one, and more.

Read the blog post

 

SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud

In this post, SAP‚Äôs @Ammar_Naji points out that SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud are core components of SAP Business Data Cloud -- and that they soon won‚Äôt be on the list of eligible services under certain subscriptions. He explains what customers can do to prepare for these changes.

Read the blog post

 

Tree View in the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

Implementing a tree view in the ABAP RESTful application programming model requires different entities, and author @Vivek_Sahu_21 covers how you can show structured, hierarchical data -- in a parent-child format -- that UI applications and analytics tools can consume easily, providing a smooth user experience.

Read the blog post

 

Community News

 

‚ÄúBlog It Forward‚Äù Is Back and Better Than Ever!

Blog It Forward is one of the longest-running initiatives in our community, dating all the way back to 2012 with this post from my colleague @moshenaveh. SAP Champion @Sandra_Solis brought the series back earlier this year with this post, and since then, several other members have contributed their own posts. The series allows members to introduce themselves while nominating other peers to participate, bringing the community closer together. Check out the Blog It Forward label to find all of the latest posts in this series, subscribe to the label to get updates when new posts appear, and consider writing one of your own!

 

Differentiating DSA Violations from Common Moderation Issues

We have taken steps to make our moderation process friendlier while ensuring that SAP Community continues to comply with the Digital Services Act (DSA). In this recent post, we outline the steps that members now should take when reporting inappropriate content to our moderation team, differentiating between common issues (e.g., incorrect tags) and true DSA violations.

 

Basic Etiquette and Tips for Participating in SAP Community

We are expanding the knowledge base in the Welcome Corner with new resources meant to help members get the most out of their SAP Community experience. In the latest post, we cover the type of behavior we expect from members, offer advice for friendly member interactions, indicate when to notify moderators, and more. Whether you‚Äôre a long-time community member or just getting started, you‚Äôll benefit from the guidance in this document.

 

Upcoming Events

 

Registration Is Live for SAP TechEd 2025

SAP TechEd is scheduled for November, and this year, we‚Äôre building a hybrid experience that brings together the best of both worlds -- a full in-person experience in Berlin and a customized virtual experience for audiences around the world. Learn more about this exciting event in this blog post from SAP's @cecihuergo and register today for SAP TechEd!

 

Find SAP CodeJam Events in Your Region

SAP CodeJam events bring together developers who want hands-on learning about SAP technology, solutions, and applications. In August, you can attend SAP CodeJam sessions in Lima (Peru), Mexico City, Bogota (Colombia), and Wroclaw (Poland). Visit the SAP CodeJam activity group to learn more about these events, and check out the full list of upcoming events.

7. –ü—ñ–¥—Ç—Ä–∏–º–∫–∞ —Ç–∞ –æ–±—Å–ª—É–≥–æ–≤—É–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—è:

  • –ü—ñ–¥—Ç—Ä–∏–º–∫–∞ –∑–∞–∫–æ–Ω–æ–¥–∞–≤—á–∏—Ö –∑–º—ñ–Ω: –∞–¥–∞–ø—Ç–∞—Ü—ñ—è –ª–æ–∫–∞–ª—ñ–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–æ—ó —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü—ñ–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—ñ –¥–æ –∑–º—ñ–Ω –≤ –∑–∞–∫–æ–Ω–æ–¥–∞–≤—Å—Ç–≤—ñ

  • –û–Ω–æ–≤–ª–µ–Ω–Ω—è —Ç–∞ –ø–∞—Ç—á—ñ: –í—á–∞—Å–Ω–µ –æ–Ω–æ–≤–ª–µ–Ω–Ω—è —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º–∏ –¥–ª—è –≤—ñ–¥–ø–æ–≤—ñ–¥–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—ñ –∑–º—ñ–Ω–∞–º –≤ –º—ñ—Å—Ü–µ–≤–æ–º—É –∑–∞–∫–æ–Ω–æ–¥–∞–≤—Å—Ç–≤—ñ —Ç–∞ —Ä–µ–≥—É–ª—è—Ç–æ—Ä–Ω–∏—Ö –≤–∏–º–æ–≥–∞—Ö.

–ó–Ω–∞–π–æ–º—Ç–µ—Å—å –∑ –Ω–∞—à–∏–º–∏ –Ω–∞–π–∫—Ä–∞—â–∏–º–∏ –µ–∫—Å–ø–µ—Ä—Ç–∞–º–∏ —Ç–∞ –ø—Ä–∏—î–¥–Ω—É–π—Ç–µ—Å—å –¥–æ —É–∫—Ä–∞—ó–Ω—Å—å–∫–æ—ó —Å–ø—ñ–ª—å–Ω–æ—Ç–∏ SAP –∑ –ª–æ–∫–∞–ª—ñ–∑–∞—Ü—ñ—ó –∑–∞–¥–ª—è –æ–±–º—ñ–Ω—É –ø–æ—Ç—Ä–µ–±–∞–º–∏, –∑–Ω–∞–Ω–Ω—è–º–∏ —Ç–∞ –¥–æ—Å–≤—ñ–¥–æ–º —Ç–∞ —É—á–∞—Å—Ç—ñ –≤ –ø—Ä–∏–π–Ω—è—Ç—Ç—ñ –Ω–∞–π–±—ñ–ª—å—à –µ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–∏—Ö —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω—å –∑ —Ä–æ–∑–≤–∏—Ç–∫—É –ª–æ–∫–∞–ª—ñ–∑–∞—Ü—ñ—ó.

–¢–µ—Ç—è–Ω–∞ –í—ñ–ª—è—î–≤–∞ ‚Äì e–∫—Å–ø–µ—Ä—Ç–∫–∞ –∑ —Ñ—ñ–Ω–∞–Ω—Å–æ–≤–∏—Ö onPrem —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω—å SAP —Ç–∞ —É–∫—Ä–∞—ó–Ω—Å—å–∫–æ–≥–æ –∑–∞–∫–æ–Ω–æ–¥–∞–≤—Å—Ç–≤–∞. –°–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º–Ω–∏–π –ø—ñ–¥—Ö—ñ–¥ –¥–æ –Ω–∞–π—Å–∫–ª–∞–¥–Ω—ñ—à–∏—Ö –∑–∞–¥–∞—á.

üìç–ì—Ä—É–ø–∞: SAP ERP (–§—ñ–Ω–∞–Ω—Å–∏ —Ç–∞ –ª–æ–≥—ñ—Å—Ç–∏–∫–∞)

–•–æ—á–µ—Ç–µ –ø–æ—Å–ø—ñ–ª–∫—É–≤–∞—Ç–∏—Å—è, –ø–æ–¥—ñ–ª–∏—Ç–∏—Å—è –¥–æ—Å–≤—ñ–¥–æ–º –∞–±–æ –¥—ñ–∑–Ω–∞—Ç–∏—Å—è –±—ñ–ª—å—à–µ –ø—Ä–æ –ª–æ–∫–∞–ª—ñ–∑–∞—Ü—ñ—é? –á—ó –≥—Ä—É–ø–∞ —á–µ–∫–∞—î –Ω–∞ –≤–∞—Å SAP ERP (–§—ñ–Ω–∞–Ω—Å–∏ —Ç–∞ –ª–æ–≥—ñ—Å—Ç–∏–∫–∞)

–Ñ–≤–≥–µ–Ω—ñ—è –ì–æ—á–µ–≤–∞ ‚Äì e–∫—Å–ø–µ—Ä—Ç–∫–∞ –∑ —É—Å—ñ—Ö HCM —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω—å SAP. –ó–Ω–∞—î –∫–æ–∂–Ω—É —Å—Ç–∞—Ç—Ç—é HR-–∑–∞–∫–æ–Ω–æ–¥–∞–≤—Å—Ç–≤–∞ —Ç–∞ –∑–Ω–∞—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –∫–æ–º–ø—Ä–æ–º—ñ—Å–∏ —É –Ω–∞–π—Å–∫–ª–∞–¥–Ω—ñ—à–∏—Ö —Å–∏—Ç—É–∞—Ü—ñ—è—Ö.

üìç–ì—Ä—É–ø–∞: HCM (–£–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª—ñ–Ω–Ω—è –ø–µ—Ä—Å–æ–Ω–∞–ª–æ–º —Ç–∞ –∑–∞—Ä–æ–±—ñ—Ç–Ω–∞ –ø–ª–∞—Ç–∞)

–ü–æ—Å–ø—ñ–ª–∫—É–≤–∞—Ç–∏—Å—è –º–æ–∂–Ω–∞ –ø—Ä–∏—î–¥–Ω–∞–≤—à–∏—Å—å –¥–æ —ó—ó –≥—Ä—É–ø–∏ –ø—Ä—è–º–æ –∑–∞—Ä–∞–∑ –ù–°–ú (–£–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª—ñ–Ω–Ω—è –ø–µ—Ä—Å–æ–Ω–∞–ª–æ–º —Ç–∞ –∑–∞—Ä–æ–±—ñ—Ç–Ω–∞ –ø–ª–∞—Ç–∞)

–Æ—Ä—ñ–π –¢–∞—Ä—á–µ–Ω–∫–æ ‚Äì e–∫—Å–ø–µ—Ä—Ç –∑ —ñ–Ω–¥—É—Å—Ç—Ä—ñ–∞–ª—å–Ω–∏—Ö —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω—å SAP, SAF-T —Ç–∞ –µ–ª–µ–∫—Ç—Ä–æ–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ –ø—ñ–¥–ø–∏—Å—É. –¢—ñ—Å–Ω–∞ —Å–ø—ñ–≤–ø—Ä–∞—Ü—è –∑ –ø–∞—Ä—Ç–Ω–µ—Ä–∞–º–∏.
üìç–ì—Ä—É–ø–∞: SAP IS-U (–Ü–Ω–¥—É—Å—Ç—Ä—ñ–∞–ª—å–Ω—ñ —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω–Ω—è –¥–ª—è –∫–æ–º—É–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω–∏—Ö –ø–æ—Å–ª—É–≥)

–Ø–∫—â–æ –≤–∏ —Ö–æ—á–µ—Ç–µ –∑–∞–Ω—É—Ä–∏—Ç–∏—Å—è –≤ –Ω—é–∞–Ω—Å–∏ –ª–æ–∫–∞–ª—ñ–∑–∞—Ü—ñ—ó, –æ–±–≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä–∏—Ç–∏ —Ç–µ—Ö–Ω—ñ—á–Ω—ñ –∞–±–æ —Ä–µ–≥—É–ª—è—Ç–æ—Ä–Ω—ñ –∞—Å–ø–µ–∫—Ç–∏ —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω—å, —á–∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–æ —Ü—ñ–∫–∞–≤–∏—Ç–µ—Å—è –Ω–∞–π–∫—Ä–∞—â–∏–º–∏ –≥–∞–ª—É–∑–µ–≤–∏–º–∏ –ø—Ä–∞–∫—Ç–∏–∫–∞–º–∏, –¥–æ—î–¥–Ω—É–π—Ç–µ—Å—å SAP IS-U (–Ü–Ω–¥—É—Å—Ç—Ä—ñ–∞–ª—å–Ω—ñ –†—ñ—à–µ–Ω–Ω—è –¥–ª—è –∫–æ–º—É–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω–∏—Ö –ø–æ—Å–ª—É–≥/Utilities)

–õ—é–¥–º–∏–ª–∞ –Ø–∫–∏–º–µ–Ω–∫–æ ‚Äì e–∫—Å–ø–µ—Ä—Ç–∫–∞ –∑ S/4HANA Public Cloud –∑ —à–∏—Ä–æ–∫–∏–º —É–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª—ñ–Ω—Å—å–∫–∏–º –¥–æ—Å–≤—ñ–¥–æ–º. –ó–Ω–∞—î –≤—Å—ñ –Ω—é–∞–Ω—Å–∏ —Ö–º–∞—Ä–Ω–æ—ó –ª–æ–∫–∞–ª—ñ–∑–∞—Ü—ñ—ó.

üìç–ì—Ä—É–ø–∞: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

–õ—é–¥–º–∏–ª–∞ –≥–æ—Ç–æ–≤–∞ –¥—ñ–ª–∏—Ç–∏—Å—è –∑ –≤–∞–º–∏ –Ω–æ–≤–∏–º–∏ –ø—ñ–¥—Ö–æ–¥–∞–º–∏ —Ç–∞ –∑–Ω–∞—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç–∏ —ñ–Ω–¥–∏–≤—ñ–¥—É–∞–ª—å–Ω—ñ —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω–Ω—è –¥–ª—è –≤–∞—à–∏—Ö –ø–æ—Ç—Ä–µ–±. –í–æ–Ω–∞ –∑ –∑–∞–¥–æ–≤–æ–ª–µ–Ω–Ω—è–º –æ–±–≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä–∏—Ç—å –≤–∞—à—ñ –±—ñ–∑–Ω–µ—Å-–∑–∞–ø–∏—Ç–∏ —Ç–∞ –ø–æ–¥—ñ–ª–∏—Ç—å—Å—è –∑–Ω–∞–Ω–Ω—è–º–∏ –≤ –≥—Ä—É–ø—ñ SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

–Ñ–≥–æ—Ä –§–µ–¥–æ—Ç–æ–≤ ‚Äì –µ–∫—Å–ø–µ—Ä—Ç —ñ–∑ SAP HCM onPrem. –ù–∞—Ä–∞–∑—ñ —Å –ª—É–∂–∏—Ç—å –£–∫—Ä–∞—ó–Ω—ñ –≤ –ª–∞–≤–∞—Ö –ó–±—Ä–æ–π–Ω–∏—Ö –°–∏–ª –£–∫—Ä–∞—ó–Ω–∏ —ñ –¥–∞—î –Ω–∞–º –º–æ–∂–ª–∏–≤—ñ—Å—Ç—å –ø—Ä–æ–¥–æ–≤–∂—É–≤–∞—Ç–∏ –ø—Ä–∞—Ü—é–≤–∞—Ç–∏ –≤ —Å–∫–ª–∞–¥–Ω—ñ —á–∞—Å–∏. –ú–∏ –∑ –Ω–µ—Ç–µ—Ä–ø—ñ–Ω–Ω—è–º —á–µ–∫–∞—î–º–æ –¥–Ω—è, –∫–æ–ª–∏ –Ñ–≥–æ—Ä –ø–æ–≤–µ—Ä–Ω–µ—Ç—å—Å—è –¥–æ –Ω–∞—Å, —ñ –≤–∏ –∑–º–æ–∂–µ—Ç–µ –æ—Å–æ–±–∏—Å—Ç–æ –æ–±–≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä–∏—Ç–∏ –∑ –Ω–∏–º –Ω–∞–π—Ç–æ–Ω—à—ñ –∞—Å–ø–µ–∫—Ç–∏ SAP HCM.

–í—Å—ñ –º–∏ —Å—å–æ–≥–æ–¥–Ω—ñ  –¥–æ–∫–ª–∞–¥–∞—î–º–æ –º–∞–∫—Å–∏–º—É–º –∑—É—Å–∏–ª—å, —â–æ–± –ø—ñ–¥—Ç—Ä–∏–º—É–≤–∞—Ç–∏ —É–∫—Ä–∞—ó–Ω—Å—å–∫–∏–π –±—ñ–∑–Ω–µ—Å. –ú–∏ –≤—ñ–¥–∫—Ä–∏—Ç—ñ –¥–æ –¥—ñ–∞–ª–æ–≥—É —Ç–∞ —Ä–∞–¥—ñ —Å–ø—ñ–≤–ø—Ä–∞—Ü—ñ, —Ç–æ–º—É –Ω–µ –≤–∞–≥–∞–π—Ç–µ—Å—è - –∑–≤–µ—Ä—Ç–∞–π—Ç–µ—Å—è!

–õ–æ–∫–∞–ª—ñ–∑–∞—Ü—ñ—è, –¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø –¥–æ —Ö–º–∞—Ä–Ω–∏—Ö —Å–µ—Ä–≤—ñ—Å—ñ–≤ —Ç–∞ —Å–ø–µ—Ü—ñ–∞–ª—å–Ω—ñ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–∏ –¥–ª—è –º–∞–ª–∏—Ö —ñ —Å–µ—Ä–µ–¥–Ω—ñ—Ö –ø—ñ–¥–ø—Ä–∏—î–º—Å—Ç–≤ –¥–æ–∑–≤–æ–ª—è—é—Ç—å –∫–æ–º–ø–∞–Ω—ñ—è–º –º–∞—Å—à—Ç–∞–±—É–≤–∞—Ç–∏—Å—è, —Ä–æ–∑–≤–∏–≤–∞—Ç–∏—Å—è –Ω–∞–≤—ñ—Ç—å –≤ —É–º–æ–≤–∞—Ö –≤—ñ–π–Ω–∏ —Ç–∞ –∑–Ω–∞—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç–∏ –Ω–æ–≤—ñ –º–æ–∂–ª–∏–≤–æ—Å—Ç—ñ –¥–ª—è –µ–∫—Å–ø–æ—Ä—Ç—É —ñ —Ü–∏—Ñ—Ä–æ–≤–æ—ó —Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—Å—Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞—Ü—ñ—ó. 

üì£–ó–∞–ª–∏—à–∞–π—Ç–µ —Å–≤–æ—ó –∫–æ–º–µ–Ω—Ç–∞—Ä—ñ —Ç–∞ –ø—Ä–æ–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü—ñ—ó, –∞–¥–∂–µ –º–∏ –ø—Ä–∞–≥–Ω–µ–º–æ –≤–¥–æ—Å–∫–æ–Ω–∞–ª–∏—Ç–∏ –Ω–∞—à—ñ —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω–Ω—è –Ω–∞ –æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤—ñ –≤–∞—à–æ–≥–æ –¥–æ—Å–≤—ñ–¥—É. –†–∞–∑–æ–º –º–∏ –∑—Ä–æ–±–∏–º–æ –≤–∞—à –±—ñ–∑–Ω–µ—Å —â–µ –±—ñ–ª—å—à –µ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–∏–º —Ç–∞ —É—Å–ø—ñ—à–Ω–∏–º –Ω–∞ –≥–ª–æ–±–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–º—É —Ä—ñ–≤–Ω—ñ.


–¢–∞–∫–æ–∂ –º–∏ –º–∞—î–º–æ —Å–≤–æ—é –≤–ª–∞—Å–Ω—É –≤–µ–±-—Å—Ç–æ—Ä—ñ–Ω–∫—É, –ø—Ä–∏—Å–≤—è—á–µ–Ω—É –∞–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—ñ SAP —É –∫—Ä–∞—ó–Ω—ñ: SAP Ukraine!

entry.title: Pedro Vieira
entry.content:
More about Pedro Vieira in SAP Community


First Name, Last Name: Pedro Vieira
Location (City, Country): Penafiel, Portugal
Occupation: Consultant

 

 


Pedro, tell us about yourself.
Who are you, what do you like to do, what is important to you?

I‚Äôm passionate about technology and I really enjoy to tinker around with new technologies and to learn new programming languages. This applies to my professional occupation but also to my personal life where, whenever possible, I use some of my free time to grow my knowledge on different technologies.


What is your area of expertise?
What does a usual day at work look like for you?

The majority of my years of experience were dedicated to integration projects ‚Äì between SAP systems and also external systems in and out of SAP. My daily activities can vary widely from supporting and actively working on the technical aspects of an integration project (coding) as well as a close advisor to the customer on how to design such a solution and tackle any challenges along the way.


What inspired you to become an SAP Champion in SAP Community?

I was challenged by Manuel Robalinho if I would be interested to join the SAP Champions group and I obviously could not decline such an offer. It is a true honor to have been accepted!


How do you learn in SAP Community?
What is your daily/weekly routine in SAP Community?

It is one of my go-to resources online every time I have a doubt or hit a roadblock in my projects. It has proven useful in the past several times and I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôll continue to be! I also keep an eye on some blog posts/tutorials on topics I follow to keep me up to date on that.


What is your suggestion to get the most out of SAP Community?

Be sure to subscribe to topics and tags related with your areas of your interest so you can receive communications when there‚Äôs new activity like blogs, news, events, or Questions/Answers. You can also keep an eye on location groups closeby to eventually discover and attend any SAP Community event, be it online or in person ‚Äì this is one of the best things the community has to offer for you to learn and build new connections!

Pedro's question to you:
What would you recommend as hot topics (or areas of interest) in the SAP community for me to follow? I‚Äôm always willing to learn üòä
